It‚Äôs Census Year! Have you completed the census yet? If not, you still can, right here: https://my2020census.gov/

Why is an accurate count on the census important for schools? The data collected from the 2020 Census will decide how much federal funding will be given to the state of Kansas, which allocates the funding to Kansas schools, until the next census count, ten years from now. This funding supports many of the programs we have in TUSD 202 that benefit our students.

The purpose of the census is to accurately count everyone living in the United States and has taken place every decade since the year 1790! You will likely receive your 2020 Census in the mail and will have the option of responding to it online, by phone, or by mail. You should have received your census and instructions on how to respond in the mail sometime in March.

If you have questions about the 2020 Census, you can contact the regional office at 1-800-852-6159.

There were two updates given today at the state level regarding the re-opening of Kansas schools for the 2020 - 2021 academic year.

Governor Kelly announced today that she will issue an Executive Order to delay the start of the school year until after Labor Day. We know there will be additional questions related to what the delay will mean for our school year calendar; we will have details regarding that in the coming weeks.

The Kansas State Board of Education approved the school reopening plan set forth by the Kansas State Department of Education. TUSD 202 is working to integrate that guidance with the ReStart WyCo Education Plan and we expect to have more operational details to provide to our families next week.

TUSD 202 continues to work diligently with state and local officials to determine the best protocols and procedures for our return to school.

We will release more details as they become available.

We have an update for our Turner USD Food Service summer meal program for this Wednesday, June 3rd.

TUSD202 has been given mixed produce boxes from the USDA to provide to families as part of our summer meal program. These boxes include mixed fruits, vegetables, and some dairy products. These boxes will be handed out on a first come first served basis this Wednesday at Turner Elementary starting at 11:00am, which is during our normal meal pick up time. We will pass out the boxes until either they are gone or 1:00pm, whichever comes first.

Families should come through the line for their student meals as usual and then once they have their student meals, they will proceed forward to a second station where they will receive the food box. Please note these boxes are only for families with students in the district.

If you have any questions, you can call our food services department at 913-288-4141.

We are excited to announce that Kansas teachers, students and parents just got a new partner in their continuous learning efforts.

Thanks to the support of Kansas Public Broadcasters, Kansas students will receive supplemental education content by way of a new television program produced by Kansas PBS stations and KSDE, and hosted by local teachers. The new program called Learning Across Kansas will begin airing the week of April 20.

Each 30-minute segment, individually produced for elementary, middle school and high school students, will feature grade-specific educational content delivered by our very own Kansas teachers who serve on KSDE‚Äôs Continuous Learning Task Force.

Teachers, students and parents/caregivers, tune in for short, fun and engaging lessons. Plus, you just might see one of your own teachers presenting!

Learn more by visiting, https://www.ksde.org/Agency/Fiscal-and-Administrative-Services/Communications-and-Recognition-Programs/Learning-Across-Kansas

We know there's a lot going on right now, but don't forget that it‚Äôs Census Year! Many families should have received their census information in the mail by now. For this census, you can conveniently submit it online!

Why is an accurate count on the census important for schools? The data collected from the 2020 Census will decide how much federal funding will be given to the state of Kansas, which allocates the funding to Kansas schools, until the next census count, ten years from now. This funding supports many of the programs we have in TUSD that benefit our students.

The purpose of the census is to accurately count everyone living in the United States and has taken place every decade since the year 1790! You will likely receive your 2020 Census in the mail and will have the option of responding to it online, by phone, or by mail. You should be receiving your census and instructions on how to respond in the mail sometime in March.

If you have questions about the 2020 Census, you can contact the regional office at 1-800-852-6159.

We are so proud of our many students who participated in Model UN last week, including our students who held leadership positions, Anaia Johnson and Kaia Seitz.

Anaia Johnson was named Secretary General, which means she ran the entire conference! Kaia Seitz served as president of a 7th grade council - another great honor!

The 56th annual Model United Nations conference hosted nearly 650 students from around the state of Kansas. The Topeka Model United Nations is a two-day simulation where student delegates represent the point of view of UN member nations on a variety of issues that we face on a global scale. The simulation is designed to foster debate, teach diplomacy, problem solving skills, and most importantly introduce students to global issues that will affect them.

Students spent months preparing for this event with the help of TAG teacher Ms. Hammes. Congratulations to all students who participated!

It‚Äôs Census Year! Why is an accurate count on the census important for schools? The data collected from the 2020 Census will decide how much federal funding will be given to the state of Kansas, which allocates the funding to Kansas schools, until the next census count, ten years from now. This funding supports many of the programs we have in TUSD that benefit our students.

The purpose of the census is to accurately count everyone living in the United States and has taken place every decade since the year 1790! You will likely receive your 2020 Census in the mail and will have the option of responding to it online, by phone, or by mail. You should be receiving your census and instructions on how to respond in the mail sometime in March.

If you have questions about the 2020 Census, you can contact the regional office at 1-800-852-6159.

Winter weather has arrived! Please read below for reminders from TUSD Transportation of how to safely get your children to and from school on the winter weather days:

Remind your child to maintain a safe distance (at least six feet away from the street) and wait for the bus to fully stop before approaching it.

Always remain visible! If children need to cross the street, make sure the driver can see them by walking at least ten feet in front of the bus. Also, never walk behind the bus.

Please be patient. Our bus drivers and transportation staff are doing their best to put student safety first while getting students to and from school. We so appreciate the work they do. If your child misses their bus, please contact your school secretary about it.

You can see her heartwarming reaction in the below video. We agree with Dr. Watson - we are so glad that Ms. Cox chose to teach in the Turner School District!

The Kansas Horizon Award program recognizes exemplary first-year teachers who perform in a way that distinguishes them as outstanding. Each year, there are a total of 32 Horizon Award recipients, 16 secondary and 16 elementary, chosen from all of the first year teachers across the state. Mr. Lewis and Ms. Hanna took several Turner High School students to Eudora to audition for a spot in the all-district choir/band. Three students were selected to perform in their all-district music group:

Choir: Quincey Murray & Kaitlynn Daniels

These groups are comprised of 100+ musicians from local area high schools, and will perform in a concert together on December 7th in Topeka. "Mr. Lewis and I are extremely proud of all of the students who auditioned. We believe the last student to audition and be accepted into an all-district group would have been in 2007, so we are absolutely stoked for our students!" said Ms. Hanna

Classified November #BESTIE Ann Harmon, Kitchen Manager at Midland Trail

Nomination Statements: Ann has worked for the district for 30+ years. She is currently the Kitchen Manager at Midland Trail. Ann sets the direction that we are one team, the food service team. She makes sure her team stays student-focused and does all she can to make their day. Ann builds positive long-lasting relationships with the students/parents; in fact, I remember Ann when I was a student here. Parents feel free to call and ask for Ann's help. Ann also knows most of her students, if not all, by name. Ann is a leader and someone the entire food service team seeks knowledge and skills from. She even stepped in to help with the office and billing when we had someone on leave. She did this without hesitation and continued to complete her daily tasks, not to mention she did not ask for anything in return. Ann is a true #BESTIE to not only Food Service, but to the students and staff as well.

Tell us in the comments what you love about Ann, our Certified #BESTIE for the month of November!
